choices.text: Gestational diabetes mellites
Effect of valproate
Hypertensive on ACE inhibitors

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pre – gestational diabetes

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shown is of Sirenomelia/ mermaid syndrome
  • Sirenomelia is the most specific anomaly seen in pregestational (overt) diabetes
  • The most common anomaly seen in pregestational (overt) diabetes is cardiovascular anomalies (VSD).

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Gestational diabetes is NOT associated with an increased incidence of fetal anomalies

 

  • Option C. Sodium Valproate is an antiepileptic drug (AED) and is associated with orofacial clefting, neural tube defects (NTDs) and cardiac anomalies. Amongst all AEDs, Valproate has the highest incidence of congenital anomalies (4-8-fold higher)

 

  • Option D. ACE inhibitors are associated with fetal renal ischemia and oligohydramnios-pulmonary hypoplasia sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • The image shown is of Sirenomelia/ mermaid syndrome
  • Sirenomelia is the most specific anomaly seen in pregestational (overt) diabetes
  • The most common anomaly seen in pregestational (overt) diabetes is cardiovascular anomalies (VSD).
  • Gestational diabetes is NOT associated with an increased incidence of fetal anomalies

 

Ref: Page no 1100, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: What could be a possible teratogenic agent that has caused this anomaly?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Thalidomide

 

Explanation:

 

  • The characteristic anomaly caused by Thalidomide is phocomelia (Absence of 1 or more long bone): Described in the Thalidomide tragedy in the USA form 1956-1960

 

Other options:

 

  • Methotrexate: Craniosynostosis with a clover leaf skull, wide nasal bridge, low set ears and micrognathia
  • Phenytoin: Fetal hydantoin syndrome (upturned nose, midfacial hypoplasia, distal digital hypoplasia)
  • Doxycycline: tetracyclines: yellowish-brownish discoloration of deciduous teeth when used after 25 weeks of gestation

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • The characteristic anomaly caused by Thalidomide is phocomelia (Absence of 1 or more long bone): Described in the Thalidomide tragedy in the USA form 1956-1960

 

Ref: Page no 246, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Which of the following medication should never be used in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Methotrexate

 

Explanation:

 

  • Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist and is potent teratogen
  • Methotrexate causes craniosynostosis with a clover leaf skull, wide nasal bridge, low set ears and micrognathia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Chloroquine use should not be withheld where indicated on account of pregnancy.
  • Cyclosporine and pyrazinamide are category C in pregnancy (should be used only when benefits outweigh the risks)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Teratogenic Drugs

 

 

Ref: Page no 246, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Maternal use of which of the following hormone may cause hypospadias in a male child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Diethylstilbesterol

 

Explanation:

 

  • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic nonsteroidal estrogen that was used to prevent miscarriage and other pregnancy complications between 1938 and 1971
  • In the United States. In 1971, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration issued a warning about the use of DES during pregnancy after a relationship between DES and the development of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix was found in women whose mothers had taken diethylstilbestrol while they were pregnant.
  • Effects of DES exposure in utero on girls
    • Cervix: hypoplastic cervix, Cockscomb cervix, cervical collar, pseudo polyp
    • Vagina: Clear cell adenocarcinoma, adenosis
    • Uterus: T-shaped uterus
  • Effects of DES exposure in utero on boys:
    • Epididymal cysts
    • Microphallus
    • Undescended testes and small testes. 
    • Hypospadias

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Tolbutamide: Insufficient studies; no major teratogenic effect noted till now
  • Option B. Clomiphene: Some association with defects like NTDs and hypospadias has been found but larger studies are required.
  • Option D. Clonazepam: Associated with orofacial clefts

 

*Hence the answer to this question should be DES and not Clomiphene as the evidence for DES causing hypospadias is higher

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic nonsteroidal estrogen that was used to prevent miscarriage and other pregnancy complications between 1938 and 1971

 

  • In the United States. In 1971, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration issued a warning about the use of DES during pregnancy after a relationship between DES and the development of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix was found in women whose mothers had taken diethylstilbestrol while they were pregnant.
  • Effects of DES exposure in utero on girls
    • Cervix: hypoplastic cervix, Cockscomb cervix, cervical collar, pseudo polyp
    • Vagina: Clear cell adenocarcinoma, adenosis
    • Uterus: T-shaped uterus
  • Effects of DES exposure in utero on boys:
    • Epididymal cysts
    • Microphallus
    • Undescended testes and small testes. 
    • Hypospadias

 

Ref: Page no 244, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition; AAFP 2004: DES exposure

questions.text: Mobius syndrome in fetus may be caused by maternal intake of
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Misoprostol

 

Explanation

 

Möbius syndrome is:

 

  • A rare congenital neurological disorder
  • Characterized by facial paralysis and the inability to move the eyes from side to side
  • Most people with Möbius syndrome are born with complete facial paralysis and cannot close their eyes or form facial expressions.
  • Limb and chest wall abnormalities sometimes occur with the syndrome.
  • Associated with prenatal exposure to misoprostol and thalidomide

 

Other options:

 

  • Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist and is a potent teratogen; Methotrexate can cause craniosynostosis with a clover leaf skull, wide nasal bridge, low set ears and micrognathia.
  • Mifepristone is not teratogenic. However, in early pregnancy it can lead to abortions and is also used for induction of labor at term
  • Dinoprostone is Prostaglandin E2; it is not teratogenic and is used for induction of labor at term

 

Educational Objective:

 

Möbius syndrome is:

 

  • A rare congenital neurological disorder
  • Characterized by facial paralysis and the inability to move the eyes from side to side
  • Most people with Möbius syndrome are born with complete facial paralysis and cannot close their eyes or form facial expressions.
  • Limb and chest wall abnormalities sometimes occur with the syndrome.
  • Associated with prenatal exposure to misoprostol and thalidomide

 

Ref: Neuromuscular disorders of infancy, childhood and adolescence,2nd edition chapter 46, pg922-957, Page no 244, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Fetal hydantoin syndrome is seen due to antenatal exposure to which drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phenytoin

 

Explanation

 

  • Phenytoin
    •  Is associated with a 3-fold increase in fetal malformations
    • Fetal hydantoin syndrome:
      • Upturned nose
      • Midfacial hypoplasia
      • Distal digital hypoplasia

 

Other Options:

 

  • Amlodipine is not associated with increased incidence of fetal malformations
  • Metformin is not associated with increased incidence of fetal malformations
  • Retinoic acid: Retinoic acid embryopathy: Ventriculomegaly, maldevelopment of facial bone or cranium, microtia or anotia, micrognathia, cleft palate, conotruncal heart defects and thymic aplasia

 

Ref: Page no 240, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Neural tube defects

questions.text: A woman comes for pre-conceptional counselling. She is a known hypertensive and is taking losartan. She is explained that she needs to change the antihypertensive to a safer non teratogenic drug. She asks you what the possible effects of losartan on the fetus are.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Renal anomalies

 

Explanation:

 

ACE inhibitors and ARBs cause:

 

  • Fetal renal hypoperfusion leading to subsequent ischemia and anuria. This leads to oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • This leads to: limb contractures, calvarium maldevelopment and Fetal growth restriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors and ARBs cause:

 

  • Fetal renal hypoperfusion leading to subsequent ischemia and anuria. This leads to oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • This leads to: limb contractures, calvarium maldevelopment and Fetal growth restriction.

 

Ref: Page 241, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 26-year-old Primigravida presents at 33 weeks in preterm labor. All the following can be given as tocolysis except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Indomethacin

 

Explanation:

 

  • Indomethacin is a tocolytic but may cause constriction of the fetal ductus arteriosus and subsequent pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • Risk of closure is higher is taken after 32 weeks for > 72 hours
  • Hence, beyond 32 weeks, indomethacin is not given for tocolysis.

 

Other options A) Atosiban, C) Nifedipine and D) Magnesium sulphate can be safely given in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Indomethacin is a tocolytic but may cause constriction of the fetal ductus arteriosus and subsequent pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • Risk of closure is higher is taken after 32 weeks for > 72 hours
  • Hence, beyond 32 weeks, indomethacin is not given for tocolysis.

 

Ref: Page no 241, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Lithium in pregnancy is associated with an increased incidence of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ebstein anomaly

 

Explanation:

 

  • Lithium has been associated with Ebstein anomaly
  • This is an otherwise rare anomaly but has a 3% risk in women on Lithium.
  • Fetal ECHO is indicated in women on Lithium

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lithium has been associated with Ebstein anomaly
  • This is an otherwise rare anomaly but has a 3% risk in women on Lithium.
  • Fetal ECHO is indicated in women on Lithium

 

Ref: Page no 245, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Continue warfarin throughout pregnancy
Replace warfarin with heparin in the 1st trimester

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a known cardiac disease presents to you in the first trimester. She gives a history of warfarin intake. What should be advised now?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Replace Warfarin with heparin in the 1st trimester

 

Explanation:

 

A patient who is on warfarin is at risk of warfarin embryopathy so she should be shifted to heparin in the 1st trimester. In the 2nd trimester, warfarin can be re-started. In the 3rd trimester, we again must shift to heparin.

 

Other options

 

  • Option A. Continue warfarin throughout pregnancy: Warfarin is unsafe in the 1st trimester (risk of warfarin embryopathy) and in the 3rd trimester (Risk of intra-cranial hemorrhage in the fetus)
  • Option B. Give coumarin: Warfarin is a coumarin
  • Option C. Stop warfarin: This will increase her risk of thrombo-embolism so it should not be stopped

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Warfarin is known to crosses the placenta and is teratogenic and causes warfarin embryopathy
  • Warfarin embryopathy - stippled epiphysis and nasal hypoplasia
  • It can also cause CNS defects and developmental delay
  • Results from fetal exposure between the 6th and 9th weeks
  • In the 3rd trimester there is a risk of hemorrhage into fetal structures
  • Hence, switch over to heparin preconceptionally or in the first trimester and then again in the third trimester.

 

Ref: Page no 247, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Cleft lip and palate

questions.text: Tobacco in pregnancy is associated with all the following birth defects except
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Renal anomalies

 

Explanation:

 

Renal anomalies are unlikely to be seen in tobacco and cigarette smoking

 

Tobacco and cigarette smoking have been associated with the following adverse effects:

 

  • Poland sequence (2-fold higher risk): unilateral aplasia of chest wall muscles and webbed fingers
  • Cardiac anomalies
  • Hydrocephaly, microcephaly
  • Omphalocele, gastroschisis
  • Cleft lip and palate
  • Hand abnormalities
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Preterm birth
  • Placenta previa
  • Abruptio placentae
  • Spontaneous abortion
  • Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)
  • Increased risk of childhood asthma and obesity

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tobacco and cigarette smoking have been associated with the following adverse effects:

 

  • Poland sequence (2-fold higher risk): unilateral aplasia of chest wall muscles and webbed fingers
  • Cardiac anomalies
  • Hydrocephaly, microcephaly
  • Omphalocele, gastroschisis
  • Cleft lip and palate
  • Hand abnormalities
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Preterm birth
  • Placenta previa
  • Abruptio placentae
  • Spontaneous abortion
  • Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)
  • Increased risk of childhood asthma and obesity

 

Ref: Page no 249, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 23-year woman has been taking isotretinoin for acne. She now is recently married and is planning conception.  After how long of stopping isotretinoin should she conceive?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3 months

 

Explanation:

 

Isotretinoin is a potent teratogen and is absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy due to its association with retinoic acid embryopathy, which can involve the CNS, face, heart, and thymus. It can result in serious fetal anomalies such as ventriculomegaly, craniofacial malformations (including microtia/anotia and cleft palate), conotruncal cardiac defects, and thymic aplasia or hypoplasia.

 

Although standard guidelines (such as the iPLEDGE program) require that women use two reliable forms of contraception for at least 1 month before, during, and for 1 month after discontinuing isotretinoin, some authoritative sources advise extending the duration to 3 months before attempting conception. This is because isotretinoin and its active metabolites cross the placenta and have a long tissue half-life in some individuals.

 

Hence, the safest and most conservative approachparticularly when counseling a 23-year-old woman planning conception after isotretinoin therapyis to advise a waiting period of 3 months after stopping isotretinoin before trying to conceive.

 

Option C. 3 months: This is the correct answer as it reflects a conservative and safe window to prevent teratogenic exposure during early embryogenesis. Though the iPLEDGE program recommends a minimum of 1 month, many clinicians follow the 3-month rule to ensure complete drug clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3 days: Incorrect. This duration is insufficient to eliminate isotretinoin and its metabolites. Given its strong teratogenicity, pregnancy must be avoided for much longer than 3 days after discontinuation.

 

Option B. 3 weeks: Incorrect. Although 3 weeks (just under 1 month) might seem close to the minimum 1-month guideline, it still falls short of the required safety window. The official recommendation is at least 1 month, and many sources support a 3-month precautionary gap.

 

Option D. 3 years: Incorrect. This is excessive and unnecessary. Isotretinoin does not persist in the body for years. A 3-year delay is not supported by any clinical guidelines or evidence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Women planning conception should wait for at least 1 monthand preferably up to 3 monthsafter stopping isotretinoin before attempting pregnancy, due to its potent teratogenic effects.

choices.text: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
Congenital pulmonary airway malformation
Primary pulmonary HTN

questions.text: A 34-year primi is started on sertraline for depression at 24 weeks gestation. She is worried about the risks the fetus can have because of the drug. What can the fetus develop?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Primary pulmonary HTN

 

SSRIs are known to cause:

 

  • Primary pulmonary hypertension if started late in pregnancy.
  • Neonatal behavioral syndrome
  • Paroxetine is associated with fetal cardiac anomalies like VSD

 

Educational Objective:

 

SSRIs are known to cause:

 

  • Primary pulmonary hypertension if started late in pregnancy.
  • Neonatal behavioral syndrome
  • Paroxetine is associated with fetal cardiac anomalies like VSD

 

Ref: Page no 245, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is concerned about potential teratogenic effects on her developing fetus. Which of the following medications, if taken during pregnancy, is associated with an increased risk of CNS defects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Warfarin

 

Explanation: Warfarin is an anticoagulant medication that, if taken during pregnancy causes stippled epiphysis and nasal hypoplasia, it is also associated with an increased risk of CNS defects. It should be avoided during pregnancy, and alternative anticoagulation methods should be considered.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Folic acid supplementation is used for the prevention of neural tube defects.
  • Option C and D: Indomethacin and aspirin are NSAIDs. Aspirin is not a major risk factor for birth defects. Indomethacin when taken late in pregnancy may cause constriction of the fetal ductus arteriosus and fetal pulmonary hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin is an anticoagulant medication that, if taken during pregnancy causes stippled epiphysis and nasal hypoplasia, it is also associated with an increased risk of CNS defects. It should be avoided during pregnancy, and alternative anticoagulation methods should be considered.

 

Ref: Page no 247, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman is prescribed a medication for her chronic medical condition. She asks if this medication is a teratogen. The physician explains that this medication can potentially cause limb and ear malformations if taken during pregnancy. Which medication is the physician most likely referring to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Valproic acid

 

Explanation: Valproic acid, an antiepileptic medication, is associated with an increased risk of limb and ear malformations when taken during pregnancy. It is considered a teratogen, and alternative medications should be considered for pregnant women with epilepsy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A, B and D: (penicillin, prednisone, omeprazole) are generally considered safer choices during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Valproic acid, an antiepileptic medication, is associated with an increased risk of limb and ear malformations when taken during pregnancy.
  • It is considered a teratogen, and alternative medications should be considered for pregnant women with epilepsy.

 

Ref: Page no 240, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Only during labor and delivery

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman presents for her first prenatal visit. She is a healthcare worker and asks about the potential teratogenic effects of her occupational exposure to radiation. What is the most critical period during pregnancy when exposure to ionizing radiation poses the highest risk of teratogenic effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. First trimester

 

Explanation: Exposure to ionizing radiation during the first trimester of pregnancy poses the highest risk of teratogenic effects, as this is the period when the developing embryo is most sensitive to radiation. It can result in structural abnormalities and organ malformations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Exposure to ionizing radiation during the first trimester of pregnancy poses the highest risk of teratogenic effects

 

Ref: Page no 906, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Occasional moderate alcohol consumption is safe during pregnancy.
Heavy alcohol use is safe in the first trimester.
Alcohol consumption should be completely avoided during pregnancy.
Alcohol is safe to consume after the first trimester.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman seeks advice about alcohol consumption during pregnancy. What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding alcohol use during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Alcohol consumption should be completely avoided during pregnancy.

 

Explanation:

 

  • The most appropriate recommendation regarding alcohol use during pregnancy is that it should be completely avoided.
  • Prenatal alcohol exposure can lead to a range of developmental and behavioral issues, collectively known as fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD). These include defects of the cardiac, skeletal, renal system as well as eye and ear defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prenatal alcohol exposure can lead to a range of developmental and behavioral issues, collectively known as fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD). These include defects of the cardiac, skeletal, renal system as well as eye and ear defects.

 

Ref: Page no 239, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Cleft lip and palate

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman with a history of uncontrolled diabetes is concerned about the potential teratogenic effects of her condition on her developing fetus. What is the common  teratogenic risk associated with maternal diabetes during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cardiac malformations

 

Explanation:

 

  • Maternal diabetes during pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of cardiac malformations in the developing fetus.
  • The most common anomaly seen in pregestational (overt) diabetes is cardiovascular anomalies (VSD).
  • Poorly controlled maternal blood glucose levels can lead to structural heart defects, making it important to manage diabetes rigorously during pregnancy to reduce this risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common anomaly seen in pregestational (overt) diabetes is cardiovascular anomalies (VSD).

 

Ref: Page no 1100, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition
